item.title: How to organize a project - The most important talk you never heard!
Towards accurate prediction of T cell targets
item.description: Goal: The cellular immune response is to a high degree defined by T cells that scrutinize the surface of cells for the presence of immunological targets (peptides presented by Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on the surface of most cells in the host). The understanding of cellular immunology has advanced significantly over the last decades, and has led to the identification and characterization of many of the essential factors that dictate if a given protein fragment will be an antigen, i.e. be able to induce an immune response. However, one essential part of this knowledge-space remains poorly resolved, namely the rules that define the T cell receptor (TCR) specificity towards individual peptide-MHC (pMHC) antigenic targets. The main objective of this project is to investigate the rules that guide TCR interactions with their cognate antigen targets; then, based upon these rules, to develop an accurate prediction model to identify antigen targets of a given TCR based on its protein sequence. PI: Professor Morten Nielsen

item.title: SigniSite: Identification of residue-level genotype-phenotype correlations in protein multiple sequence alignments.
